snippet.textDisplay: Coming so late to the party, I find somewhat ironic the part that mentions closing the "dirties" energy-producing facilities (based on coal) and allowing the nuclear ones to live more. The energy crisis related to the Russian invasion of Ukraine forced some European countries to do the exact opposite (reopen some coal-based power plants).

snippet.textDisplay: Wow, just learned that a lot of the "impartial scientific findings" backing up Kurzgesagt videos is in fact entirely not impartial. Instead this channel is almost entirely funded, supported, and run by Bill Gates and a collection of other billionaires. I am sick and tired of being manipulated by good PR and "facts" that are instead cheery interpretations of fabricated data. I am unsubscribing and taking everyone I brought to this channel with me. I hope others do the same. Do not support this channel, its a PR mouthpiece of elite billionaires.

snippet.textDisplay: @Richard Blazer  In no way did my comment imply that humans do not have an effect on the environment e.g. chopping down trees. Although global tree cover increased by 7% between 1982 and 2018. And it should also be noted that the Earth has got a lot greener over the last four decades, with over 40% of the Earth's land surface experiencing significant greening. This is largely due to the fertilising effect of the extra CO2 in the atmosphere. Seems like a positive effect to me.
snippet.textOriginal: @Richard Blazer  In no way did my comment imply that humans do not have an effect on the environment e.g. chopping down trees. snippet.textDisplay:
@Old Scientist I don’t think you know what a non sequitur is.

It’s actually a very simple and effective analogy, as many people, such as yourself, claim climate change occurs naturally, therefore humans can b it significantly affect the climate.
This is analogous to claiming that trees can fall down due to many natural reasons, therefore humans can significantly affect the number of trees in an area. It’s quite applicable.
@Richard Blazer No. That is a complete non sequitur.
snippet.textOriginal: @Richard Blazer No. That is a complete non sequitur.

snippet.textDisplay: The problem is humanity itself. We assume people are rational enough to recognize problems and altruistic enough to not abuse or corrupt any process. But the reality is that people still believe in a flat earth, or an invisible being in the sky who tells them that our physical environment is only temporary and not necessary to be loved and cared for, etc. Even the best education won't convert the stubborn among us. Even the most powerful governments can't even stop a protest once it gets violent. When your job, comfort and family are under threat, you will rather die from bullets than by rising sea levels. No, the problem is humanity and climate change is here to stay, and humanity will either adapt to the new environment or die.
snippet.textOriginal: The problem is humanity itself. We assume people are rational enough to recognize problems and altruistic enough to not abuse or corrupt any process. Even the most powerful governments can't even stop a protest once it gets violent. When your job, comfort and family are under threat, you will rather die from bullets than by rising sea levels. No, the problem is humanity and climate change is here to stay, and humanity will either adapt to the new environment or die.

snippet.textDisplay:
Believe in climate change?
No AC
No heat unless you live where it gets below freezing, then only 60 degrees
Move closer to work so you can bike or walk
Don't be overweight, eat no meat if you think that's an issue
Don't buy more clothes etc. You probably have all you need

The above uses far less energy then producing dirty solar panels and wind turbines and the dirty electric car batteries.

The above is never talked about because where is the control and money in those ideas?

we see we are having these Co² issues for the last decades because of massive emittions of power supply of all countries in the world because of the faster growth of techonlogy and population and the demand of power supply in increasing each year, but if we can discipline our self to reduce the energy consumption it might sound controling people but hear me out, at our home we don't really need to rely on electricity for example at our homes we just simply unplug unessesary device or appliances to grealty reduce the electricity bills and at the sametime we can help to reduce the Co² emmitons in short ways we need to analyze the electricity consumption in our homes to reduce it as far as possible we get to the point that we can save energy and at the sametime a money right?

and we know that rich people houses are the ones who consume massive amounts of energy simply because almost all of their appliances are all working on electricity but we can't stop them theyre rich tho so we can't do anything about it but with a good advices from each of our governments and enough information that they can anounce to us on advertisment or local door to door information papers to read by each household to aware us about Green house effect together we can reduce the amount of Co² emmitions to normal rates instead of fighting who's right or wrong why would we just work together to massively reduce the electicity consumption.

in conclusion as we know we can't simply remove fossil fuels power plants to massively reduce the co² emittions but we can take control by every little move and dicipline on energy demand in little ways so it can have massive impact of reducing this Global warming effect that we currently facing at as human species

snippet.textDisplay:
Also, think of the many ways we can and do produce electricity versus you cannot create gas and etc without fossil fuels. As demands for electricity grows, while emissions produced by the increasing infrastructure and production may rise that doesn’t mean they do so equally with the reduction in fossil fuel energy emissions.

That is, the emissions from building a new hydropower plant (that meets the energy deficit with the destruction of a fossil fuel plant) isn’t the same as what a coal plant produces.
snippet.textOriginal:
Also, think of the many ways we can and do produce electricity versus you cannot create gas and etc without fossil fuels. As demands for electricity grows, while emissions produced by the increasing infrastructure and production may rise that doesn’t mean they do so equally with the reduction in fossil fuel energy emissions.

That is, the emissions from building a new hydropower plant (that meets the energy deficit with the destruction of a fossil fuel plant) isn’t the same as what a coal plant produces.

snippet.textDisplay:
Electric cars produce emissions in production and in power generation for them. Increased demand further helps drive electricity demand and infrastructure (green and not).

They also don’t produce smog and as resources shift from electricity from fossil fuels/refinement/gas production that doesn’t equate to the emissions equally rising.

Though the goal isn’t necessarily to have less people driving and/or traveling.
snippet.textOriginal:

Though the goal isn’t necessarily to have less people driving and/or traveling.

snippet.textDisplay: Again you are confusing "weather" with "climate". But the real issue is who and how/much benefits from all this "global warming" and "climate change" crap. It the usual left wing cucks who exploit the insecurities and sensitivities of the rest of us. Wake up and send these idiots home. Humans are not able to control/alter the earth's climate but we can try to be more sensible about preserving our limited resources. For the last time: The "global warming" scare was a hoax, it never happened; they just could not prove it. So they changed their tune and started calling it "climate change". Well when it starts snowing in Sahara or the earth's poles REALLY start melting, because so far they're thriving, THEN we can safely conclude that the climate has changed. But there's nothing humans can do to alter that vastly remote possibility. Until then understand that what drives climate on earth is basically the Sun and that will not fade for another ... 5 Billion years! So kick back, relax, and enjoy your local weather for now. Our VERY distant descendants, if they are still humans and not some alien mutated mix, will have to deal with that and I hope they will have developed the technology to mitigate that scenario. Cheers!
snippet.textOriginal: Again you are confusing "weather" with "climate". But the real issue is who and how/much benefits from all this "global warming" and "climate change" crap. It the usual left wing cucks who exploit the insecurities and sensitivities of the rest of us. Wake up and send these idiots home. Humans are not able to control/alter the earth's climate but we can try to be more sensible about preserving our limited resources. For the last time: The "global warming" scare was a hoax, it never happened; they just could not prove it. So they changed their tune and started calling it "climate change". Well when it starts snowing in Sahara or the earth's poles REALLY start melting, because so far they're thriving, THEN we can safely conclude that the climate has changed. But there's nothing humans can do to alter that vastly remote possibility. Until then understand that what drives climate on earth is basically the Sun and that will not fade for another ... 5 Billion years! So kick back, relax, and enjoy your local weather for now. Our VERY distant descendants, if they are still humans and not some alien mutated mix, will have to deal with that and I hope they will have developed the technology to mitigate that scenario. Cheers!

snippet.textDisplay:
Sadly,the age of innovation is over.
There is no magical technologie or innovation that will save us.
We already have those innovations and technogies.
What is lackimg id applying them.


Example.
Electric cars were efficient and affordable afor at least a decade or more.
But it took a man with great advertising skills to push people andthe economy into actually producing electric cars regularly, and build the infrastructure they need.

Same with everything else.

We have the tech.
We need to use it!

Thats why I keep saying "The age of innovation is over. The age of applying science is here."

snippet.textDisplay:
“Net-Zero” is missing some explanation here: It actually means that carbon emissions will still be produced, but they will be “offset”. One measure for example is forestation. However, increasing temperatures reduce the carbon offsetting potential of plants. Another natural example are earths oceans which are the main carbon dioxide absorber. As for the plants the effectivity decreases with raising global temperatures. Other examples are renewable technologies which require big investments making it profitable for businesses.
My main takeaway is that everyone is just waiting for that magical technology that saves us all :(
snippet.textOriginal:

As for the plants the effectivity decreases with raising global temperatures. Other examples are renewable technologies which require big investments making it profitable for businesses.
